paragraphs.text:
%md
# Using the Data Stores tab, upload the log file(s)

For this exercise, please create a new HDFS directory /tmp/logfiles
Then upload the file(s) to the HDFS: /tmp/logfiles directory

msg.data:
Using the Data Stores tab, upload the log file(s)

For this exercise, please create a new HDFS directory /tmp/logfiles
Then upload the file(s) to the HDFS: /tmp/logfiles directory

paragraphs.title: Open up the permissions to Hive & Spark SQL
paragraphs.text:
%sh
# For simplicity, we will make /tmp/logfiles open to everyone.  I could do this more precisely, but I am on a plane...
sudo -u hdfs hadoop fs -chmod -R 777 /tmp/logfiles
echo "done"

%md
# Speaking of Regular Expressions...

Here is an awesome website for Regular Expression development:
https://regexr.com/


Note: I made these changes to the given regexp:

    I did a search replace for \ to \\
    I did a search replace for (\\".*?\\") to \\"(.*?)\\"
    
The first is just because Zeppelin likes to add another interpretation of \ as a special character.
The second is to move the "" outside of the grouping expressions.  This removes the "" from each data value.

msg.data:
Speaking of Regular Expressions…

Here is an awesome website for Regular Expression development:
https://regexr.com/

Note: I made these changes to the given regexp:

I did a search replace for \ to \\
I did a search replace for (\\".*?\\") to \\"(.*?)\\"

The first is just because Zeppelin likes to add another interpretation of \ as a special character.
The second is to move the "“ outside of the grouping expressions. This removes the ”" from each data value.

paragraphs.title: Define a Hive External table
paragraphs.text:
%sh 


# use the hive CLI. I like the CLI because it gives better error messages if you do something wrong
hive <<EOF
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS logs;

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE logs (
   timestmp string,
   uuid string COMMENT '',
  jsessionid string COMMENT '',
  hostname string COMMENT '',
  clinicid string COMMENT '',
  screenid string COMMENT '',
  id string COMMENT '',
  name string COMMENT '',
  value string COMMENT '',
  pos string COMMENT '',
  type string COMMENT '',
  ip string COMMENT '',
  origin string COMMENT '',
  useragent string COMMENT '')
ROW FORMAT SERDE
  'org.apache.hadoop.hive.serde2.RegexSerDe'
WITH SERDEPROPERTIES (
  'input.regex'='((?:2|1)\\\\d{3}(?:-|\\\\/)(?:(?:0[1-9])|(?:1[0-2]))(?:-|\\\\/)(?:(?:0[1-9])|(?:[1-2][0-9])|(?:3[0-1]))(?:T|\\\\s)(?:(?:[0-1][0-9])|(?:2[0-3])):(?:[0-5][0-9]):(?:[0-5][0-9])).*?\\"(.*?)\\".*?\\"(.*?)\\".*?\\"(.*?)\\".*?\\"(.*?)\\".*?\\"(.*?)\\".*?\\"(.*?)\\".*?\\"(.*?)\\".*?\\"(.*?)\\".*?\\"(.*?)\\".*?\\"(.*?)\\".*?\\"(.*?)\\".*?\\"(.*?)\\".*?\\"(.*?)\\"')
STORED AS INPUTFORMAT
  'org.apache.hadoop.mapred.TextInputFormat'
OUTPUTFORMAT
  'org.apache.hadoop.hive.ql.io.HiveIgnoreKeyTextOutputFormat'
LOCATION
 '/tmp/logfiles';
  

SELECT * FROM logs limit 20;

exit;

EOF
# Hint: I did a search/replace for / with // on the original regexp.
# I also moved the \" outside of the grouping sets to remove the " from the data values
# And I changed the column timestamp to be called timestmp to avoid reserved word

paragraphs.title: See what tables we have (now using Spark SQL)

default	bike_trips	false
default	bike_trips_objectstore	false
default	bike_trips_objectstore_bdfs	false

	bike_trips_temp	true
	holidays_temp	true
	weather_temp	true

paragraphs.title: Optional optimization: Make a parquet version of our table
paragraphs.text:
%sql
create table logs_parquet
stored as parquet
as select * from logs

paragraphs.title: Some query fun
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select type, count(*)
  from logs_parquet
 group by type

paragraphs.title: More query fun
paragraphs.text:
%sql
select x,y,type, count(*) num
from (select split(pos,',')[0] as x, split(pos,',')[1] as y, type from logs_parquet) logs_xy
group by x,y,type

msg.data:
x	y	type	num
1293	701	button	1
704	352	text	9
1080	499	button	2

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Next Steps

Now lets connect from a query tool...

A few things to note about Big Data Cloud in its default setup:

+ It uses the http thrift setup
+ It uses port 1080
+ It expects you to provide a valid BDC username/password (for instance, bdcsce_admin as defined during provisioning)
+ It uses SSL encryption
+ It uses a self-signed certificate
+ You should use the CAIssuedCertNamesMismatch=1 parameter
+ The HTTPPath parameter should be = cliservice

For using DVD, see the notebook under extras called "Connecting DVD4 to BDC" (assumes you used the Big Data Journeys bootstrap file at provisioning).

msg.data:
Next Steps

Now lets connect from a query tool…

A few things to note about Big Data Cloud in its default setup:

  • It uses the http thrift setup
  • It uses port 1080
  • It expects you to provide a valid BDC username/password (for instance, bdcsce_admin as defined during provisioning)
  • It uses SSL encryption
  • It uses a self-signed certificate
  • You should use the CAIssuedCertNamesMismatch=1 parameter
  • The HTTPPath parameter should be = cliservice

For using DVD, see the notebook under extras called “Connecting DVD4 to BDC” (assumes you used the Big Data Journeys bootstrap file at provisioning).
